channel.name: How to implement token escrow payment?

messages.content:
I want to withdraw tokens from contract, without needing to provide a signature, by using proofs only.

``` @method
  async withdraw(withdrawAmount: UInt64) {    
    const token = new FungibleToken(this.tokenAddress.getAndRequireEquals());
    await token.transfer(
     this.address,
     this.sender.getAndRequireSignature(),
     withdraw
    );
  }```

Calling it gives me:

`Check signature: Invalid signature on account_update `

This is despite setting send permission for proof only, and also trying it with `send: Permissions.none()`.

If I sign with the contract key, it goes through but I do not want to do so as that key would need to be shared and tx would needed to be double signed complicating thigns.

In the dex example (https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/1588ee566d15a6e5ef6a1a611386c7da578ab48a/src/examples/zkapps/dex/dex.ts#L264)  there is the following syntax:

`this.self.body.mayUseToken = AccountUpdate.MayUseToken.ParentsOwnToken;`

and in the dex with actions (https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/1588ee566d15a6e5ef6a1a611386c7da578ab48a/src/examples/zkapps/dex/dex-with-actions.ts#L283) this one:

`receiver.body.mayUseToken = AccountUpdate.MayUseToken.InheritFromParent;`

Dexes need custodial /escrow transfer, so I'm thinking this may be something I need to do.

Is that the case, and if so what is the correct way to grant permission to the contract token account to transfer funds without the need for its private key?

messages.content: Print account updates and see what’s happening?
So, token.transfer() would be called in the Mina.transaction() block, outside the method
The token contract has to "supervise" the transfer, so the transferring method cannot also "supervise" the token contract (they would form a cycle)
I hope I'm making sense

I also have a question about this example. Under the restrictions you mentioned, how can we implement the restriction in the current zkapp that the tokens owned by the zkapp can only be burned instead of transferred?

it's an interesting puzzle to solve 😄
if you accept the overhead of two additional method calls for the token contract, then I have a solution:

the token contract could have a custom `burn(a: AccountUpdate)` method which sets its own state to `isBurning = true`, then approves the input account update (and checks that it actually burns tokens!), and then calls another custom token contract method `resetBurn()` which asserts that `isBurning = true` and resets it to `isBurning = false`. There should be absolutely no way of setting `isBurning = true`  other than calling `tokenContract.burn()`.

finally, the token contract should have another custom method, `assertBurn()`, which only requires that `isBurning = true` and nothing else.

In your zkapp method, you can then call `tokenContract.assertBurn()` and it guarantees you that you're inside a `tokenContract.burn()` call. So the zkapp ensures its tokens are burnt, not transfered.
A better solution should come with a protocol upgrade where you can make assertions about your parent account updates

This does seem to be a feasible solution. 😅   However, in many cases, token contracts are used as external contracts, and zkapp developers do not have the authority to modify token contracts. At the same time, the business logic of zkapp itself should not be a matter for token contract owners to care about, so this is a big limitation. What I can think of is that it is also very difficult for zkapp to set whitelist and blacklist restrictions for token transfers it owns.

> zkapp developers do not have the authority to modify token contracts

well, on the standard token contract (https://github.com/MinaFoundation/mina-fungible-token/blob/main/FungibleToken.ts), there is no burn method at all that can be used by zkapps.

so I was assuming we're talking about "how to implement a token contract which enables zkapps to assert they are burning tokens"

> At the same time, the business logic of zkapp itself should not be a matter for token contract owners to care about, so this is a big limitation.
token contract developers should care about enabling to use their token in maximally flexible way

> What I can think of is that it is also very difficult for zkapp to set whitelist and blacklist restrictions for token transfers it owns.
This I don't see as a big problem, because the zkapp can usually _create_ the receiver account update itself, so it can define exactly what transfers it enables

so the usual flow to send from a zkapp that I imagine is
* in your zkapp method,
  * decrease your own balance
  * create a child account update that has a matching positive balance change
* outside your zkapp method, take the full tree of account updates returned by the zkapp, and give it to the token contract to approve
note that the two steps inside the zkapp method listed above are both done by `this.send()`
and to get the tree of account updates created by the zkapp, you can use `zkapp.self.extractTree()`
actually you don't need to do that, just call `tokenContract.approveAccountUpdate(zkapp.self)`, this will extract the tree under the hood

But then, even if we create valid accountUpdates to be approved by token, won't contractA privateKey be still required ?
 🤯

does the fact we using  TokenContract to control another TokenContract making it somehow diffrent?
I'll write up an example tomorrow, this will speak more than a 1000 words
But you can also look at how the Dex examples use `tokenContract.transfer()`

I'd be interested in a new implementation of the standard token to facilitate this, I find the current solution counterintuitive and complex to set up, it forces you to sign at least once with the escrow contract key, we don't have this hassle with sending mina.

why would you have to sign with the escrow contract key?

also "new implementation of the standard token" is not really the issue to solve. the underlying protocol for custom tokens is complex to use, mainly because you only can pass down one permission at a time. but to change that requires a HF

Ok @zkKirol @widly @Youtpout. I created an example that demonstrates how to withdraw custom tokens from a zkApp!
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1699/commits/e3235a7f520e84ae6ae70e7e0034780a3200aca2
also check out `withdrawOptimized()` which creates one account update less than `withdraw()`
For the dex example, the dextoken holder must be deployed with the zkapp key

why is that a problem? you would deploy it at the same time as the main dex contract itself, which also needs the zkapp key. deploying your contracts is expected to require the key, it's the same for all contracts
it's basically a proxy contract that enables the dex to hold multiple tokens
if I want to let a user create his own pool, I'll have to provide him with the key as well.
ok I see, that's undesirable! but do you think this is a fundamental problem with the token standard? maybe the token holder address could be made a parameter?
it will use the same tokenId for the receiver as the sender (= `this`) has, so in the case the sender is a custom token account, it's a custom token transfer
oh okay
in the end it just creates the receiver account update, and modifies both `this.balance` and `receiver.balance`
not very fancy
the part that's harder to figure out yourself is where we set `body.mayUseToken = ...` 😄
In my case, I'll have to deploy all the token/pool pairs with a custom contract that will manage the swap.
the signature key should be public, but they do not allow assets to be transferred or the contract to be updated
sounds like a nice solution!

on the other hand, if the signature key is public, you can't prevent anyone from creating those token accounts by themselves, and setting permissions however they like, and then locking down permissions

so maybe there shouldn't be a single hard-coded signature key, but rather people should be able to register pool contracts created with any key, and the deployment of those contracts makes sure that the creators can't manipulate them later on
so it would be up to the backend to manage this when a new pool is created, for example, but the platform would have to be at least centralized.
why?
you could use offchain state to store it, which is decentralized
I think we're off topic, we can talk about it again on one of my posts.
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1699

embeds.description:
This PR just adds two new examples for things that are not documented well

example for withdrawing custom tokens from a zkapp
example for linking of state between two zkapps

messages.content:
big thanks for the example, it does explain how to do the escrow well
but

https://github.com/KarolDevLtd/Sliced.club/blob/smallFixes3/contracts/src/GroupBasic.ts#L168
 I think in our use case `this` may not be working as
the GroupBasic(your 'TokenEscrow' ) is extended from TokenContract in our case.

https://github.com/KarolDevLtd/Sliced.club/blob/smallFixes3/contracts/src/GroupBasic.test.ts#L580
you create 
`let escrow = new TokenEscrow(escrowAccount, tokenId); `
and you use that to sign escrow.self, would we need to create new instance of GroupBasic using fungibleTokenId?

Another thing to keep in mind is that every account, and in particular every zkapp account, has just 1 token id, and can therefore hold just 1 kind of token.

It sounds like you have a token contract which is also itself supposed to hold (other) tokens.
most likely, what you need to do is have multiple zkapps deployed, to accounts with the same address (your zkapp address) but with different token ids.

and then, there's no reason to deploy one and the same contract to all those accounts. the token holder account could have different methods than the main (MINA) account.
but the fact that there are multiple zkapps that probably need to collaborate in some way complicates things. I had to solve this in the DEX examples, which use one main contract `Dex` and a proxy contract `DexTokenHolder` for each token the DEX wants to hold.

interesting, bit counter intuitive imo 
(What if one would want to use native Mina and token at the same time/method?)

Ok, guess my confusion came from assumption that if my zkapp has pubKey and it's own tokenId, if I send another token to it it would automatically just create new token account with same pubKey but different tokenId. 
We'll give a try `GroupTokenHolder`
Again thanks for help, examples and shinning some light at it all!

Thanks, I tested it and it works 😅  After looking at the current token standard contract, I found that transfers of tokens owned by zkapp are basically undetectable by the contract to emit transfer events (the current contract indeed does not consider supporting zkapp token accounts). We might need to recognize the transfer of tokens in the approveBase method and emit transfer events to facilitate data processing for some off-chain services.

Currently o1js does not seem to provide a method for zkapp to burn tokens through proof (without signature). The existing this.internal.burn method still requires the sender's signature, even if the sender passed in is a zkapp's AccountUpdate
That doesn't sound right
Burning is the same as sending in that regard
Oh sorry I misunderstood you and get what you mean! So maybe this.internal.burn() has a bug? It's not very complicated though so maybe you can write your own version
Thanks  @gregor. That's an exact example we were after and as well as an explanation why our aproach wasn't working.
Yeah, I checked the burn method and found that the sender's signature is mandatory. Im curious if AccoutUpdate.label will have any impact on the processing of transactions?

I have a question.
When a SmartContract is deployed on-chain, it can be queried as an account: https://minascan.io/devnet/account/B62qqVsWwGsd25ZaBpZKEGMiqmHaeufYqK2ACjX895RaQrMj2DZutaM/txs
When deploying using TokenContract, it also appears as a regular account: https://minascan.io/devnet/account/B62qjwDWxjf4LtJ4YWJQDdTNPqZ69ZyeCzbpAFKN7EoZzYig5ZRz8JE

Is there something that needs to be set during deployment for accounts to be queried as zkAccounts?

messages.content:
Isn't this about retrieving account information for the tokenId?
Does this have anything to do with being displayed as a zkApp on the block explorer?

I was looking for related information and ended up posting in the wrong place instead of zkApps-developer. I'm sorry about that.
No, label is for debugging inside o1js. Not part of the JSON transaction

Yeah token id doesn't seem related to what your asking. 

However, I'm not sure what you're asking. What do you mean with "being queried as zkapp accounts"? There is no separate query, a zkapp account is also just an account
There is a field on every account called "zkapp". It will typically be null for end user accounts, and contains zkapp related stuff like the verification key

일반 계정과 zkApp 계정에 대한 제 이해가 잘못된 것인지 확인하고자 질문드렸습니다.
답변을 통해 제가 이미 알고 있던 내용이 맞다는 것을 확인했습니다. 저는 잠시 블록 탐색기에 표시되는 정보에 혼동이 있었습니다.
감사합니다. 👍

> I asked the question to confirm whether my understanding of regular accounts and zkApp accounts was incorrect. Through your response, I confirmed that what I already knew was correct. I was briefly confused by the information displayed on the block explorer. Thank you. 👍

\- 4o
